subsection.title: Meaning of the Intercepts
subsection.p: The intercepts of a graph give us information about the situation it models.

The g-intercept tells us that when d = 0, g = 20, or that when Leon has traveled 0 miles, he has 20 gallons of gasoline left. The fuel tank holds 20 gallons when full.

subsection.title: General Form for a Linear Equation
subsection.p: The graphs of the equations we have seen so far are all portions of straight lines. For this reason such equations are called linear equations.

The order of the terms in the equation does not matter. For example, the equation in of
\amp C=5+3t \amp \amp \text{ can be written equivalently as } \amp -3t + C=5
and the equation in of that section,
\amp g=20-\frac{1}{12}d \amp \amp \text{ can be written as } \amp \frac{1}{12}d+g=20
This form of a linear equation, Ax +By = C, is called the general form.

subsection.p: Some linear models are easier to use when they are written in the general form.

statement.p: The manager at Albert's Appliances has $3000 to spend on advertising for the next fiscal quarter. A 30-second spot on television costs $150 per broadcast, and a 30-second radio ad costs $50.

li.p: The manager decides to buy x television ads and y radio ads. Write an equation relating x and y.
Make a table of values showing several choices for x and y.
Plot the points from your table, and graph the equation.
Each television ad costs $150, so x ads will cost $150x. Similarly, y radio ads will cost $50y. The manager has $3000 to spend, so the sum of the costs must be $3000. Thus, 150x+50y=3000

We choose some values of x, and solve the equation for the corresponding value of y. For example, if x=\alert{10} then 150(\alert{10})+50y\amp=300 1500+50y\amp=3000 50y\amp=1500 y\amp=30 If the manager buys 10 television ads, she can also buy 30 radio ads. You can verify the other entries in the table.

sidebyside.p: We plot the points from the table. All the solutions lie on a straight line.

subsection.title: Solving for y in Terms of x

li.p: Solve the equation 4x-3y=6 for y in terms of x.
Write the equation y=-9-\dfrac{3}{2}x in general linear form.

Write the equation in the form Ax+By=C.
y \amp = -9-\frac{3}{2}x\amp\amp \bluetext{\text{Add } \frac{3}{2}x \text{ to both sides.}} \frac{3}{2}x+y \amp = -9
We can write the equation with integer coefficients by clearing the fractions. We multiply both sides of the equation by \alert{2} .
\alert{2}\left(\frac{3}{2}x+y \right) \amp = -9(\alert{2}) 3x+2y \amp = -18

subsection.warning:
Do not confuse solving for y in terms of x with finding the y-intercept. Compare:
In Example 5a, we solved 4x − 3y = 6 for y in terms of x to get y = -2 +\frac{4}{3}x . This is still an equation in two variables; it is just another (equivalent) form of the original equation.
To find the y-intercept of the same equation, we first set x = 0, then solve for y, as follows:
4(0) − 3y \amp = 6 y = −2
This gives us a particular point on the graph, namely, (0, −2); the point whose x-coordinate is 0.
